_link.title: I can explain what isotopes are and how they differ from each other

toLevel2.question: What defines isotopes of the same element?
options: Same number of protons, different number of neutrons
Same number of neutrons, different number of protons
Same number of electrons, different number of protons
Same mass number, different atomic number
toLevel2.correct: Same number of protons, different number of neutrons
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Isotopes are atoms of the same element (same proton number) but with different numbers of neutrons, giving different mass numbers.

distractorExplanations.Same number of neutrons, different numbe: Different proton numbers would make them different elements, not isotopes.
distractorExplanations.Same number of electrons, different numb: Different proton numbers mean different elements, not isotopes.

toLevel2.question: Which of the following is a radioactive isotope of hydrogen?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Tritium (hydrogen-3) has 1 proton and 2 neutrons and is the only radioactive isotope of hydrogen.

distractorExplanations.Deuterium: Deuterium (hydrogen-2) has 1 proton and 1 neutron and is stable.
distractorExplanations.Hydrogen-1: Hydrogen-1 (protium) has 1 proton and 0 neutrons and is stable.
distractorExplanations.Protium: Protium is another name for hydrogen-1, which is stable.

toLevel2.question: How many neutrons does deuterium have?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Deuterium (hydrogen-2) has 1 proton and 1 neutron, giving it a mass number of 2.

distractorExplanations.0: Zero neutrons would be hydrogen-1 (protium), not deuterium.
distractorExplanations.2: Two neutrons would be tritium (hydrogen-3), not deuterium.
distractorExplanations.3: Three neutrons would give mass number 4, which is not a known hydrogen isotope.

toLevel2.question: What type of properties do isotopes of the same element share?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Isotopes have the same number of protons and electrons, so they have identical chemical properties.

distractorExplanations.Mass: Isotopes have different masses due to different neutron numbers.
distractorExplanations.Number of neutrons: Isotopes have different numbers of neutrons by definition.
distractorExplanations.Radioactivity: Some isotopes are stable while others are radioactive.

toLevel2.question: How many protons does tritium have?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Tritium is an isotope of hydrogen, so it has 1 proton like all hydrogen isotopes.

distractorExplanations.2: An atom with 2 protons would be helium, not hydrogen.
distractorExplanations.3: 3 is the mass number of tritium (1 proton + 2 neutrons), not the proton count.
distractorExplanations.0: All atoms have at least 1 proton; 0 protons would be a neutron.

toLevel2.question: Isotopes of the same element have the same number of {{c1::protons}} but different numbers of neutrons.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The number of protons defines the element. Isotopes differ only in neutron count.

toLevel2.question: Hydrogen has three isotopes: hydrogen-1, {{c1::deuterium}}, and tritium.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Deuterium is hydrogen-2, containing 1 proton and 1 neutron.

toLevel2.question: Isotopes have identical {{c1::chemical}} properties but different physical properties.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Chemical properties depend on electron configuration, which is the same for all isotopes of an element.

toLevel2.question: All isotopes of an element are radioactive.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Some isotopes are stable while others are radioactive. For example, hydrogen-1 and deuterium are stable, but tritium is radioactive.

toLevel2.question: Isotopes of the same element have the same atomic number.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The atomic number (number of protons) defines the element. All isotopes of an element have the same atomic number.

toLevel3.question: Why do isotopes of the same element have identical chemical properties?
options: They have the same number of electrons
They have the same number of neutrons
toLevel3.correct: They have the same number of electrons
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Chemical properties are determined by electron configuration. Since isotopes have the same number of protons, they have the same number of electrons and thus identical chemical behaviour.

distractorExplanations.They have the same number of neutrons: Isotopes have different numbers of neutrons by definition.
distractorExplanations.They have the same mass: Isotopes have different masses due to different neutron counts.
distractorExplanations.They are all radioactive: Not all isotopes are radioactive; many are stable.

toLevel3.question: Why is tritium radioactive while deuterium is stable?
options: Tritium has too many neutrons relative to protons
toLevel3.correct: Tritium has too many neutrons relative to protons
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Nuclear stability depends on the proton-to-neutron ratio. Tritium (1 proton, 2 neutrons) has an unfavourable ratio, making it unstable.

distractorExplanations.Tritium has fewer protons: Both tritium and deuterium have 1 proton each.
distractorExplanations.Deuterium has more neutrons: Deuterium has 1 neutron; tritium has 2 neutrons.
distractorExplanations.Tritium has no electrons: Tritium has 1 electron, like all neutral hydrogen atoms.

toLevel3.question: Why is understanding isotopes important in nuclear physics?
options: Different isotopes can be stable or radioactive
toLevel3.correct: Different isotopes can be stable or radioactive
toLevel3.correctExplanation: The neutron count affects nuclear stability. Some isotopes decay radioactively while others remain stable, which determines their applications.

distractorExplanations.All isotopes behave identically: Isotopes have different nuclear properties; some are stable, others radioactive.
distractorExplanations.Isotopes only exist for hydrogen: All elements have isotopes, not just hydrogen.
distractorExplanations.Neutrons don't affect nuclear behaviour: The number of neutrons strongly affects nuclear stability.

toLevel3.question: Why do isotopes have different physical properties?
options: They have different numbers of protons
They have different numbers of electrons
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Different neutron counts give isotopes different masses, affecting physical properties like density and rate of diffusion.

distractorExplanations.They have different numbers of protons: Isotopes have the same number of protons by definition.
distractorExplanations.They have different numbers of electrons: Neutral isotopes have the same number of electrons as protons.
distractorExplanations.They have different chemical behaviours: Isotopes have identical chemical properties, not different ones.

toLevel3.question: What determines whether an isotope will be stable or radioactive?
options: The balance of protons and neutrons in the nucleus
The physical state at room temperature
toLevel3.correct: The balance of protons and neutrons in the nucleus
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Nuclear stability depends on the proton-to-neutron ratio. An imbalance can make the nucleus unstable and prone to radioactive decay.

distractorExplanations.The number of electrons: Electrons orbit outside the nucleus and don't determine nuclear stability.
distractorExplanations.The chemical properties: Chemical properties are determined by electrons, not nuclear stability.
distractorExplanations.The physical state at room temperature: Physical state doesn't affect whether an isotope is radioactive.

toLevel3.question: Isotopes have identical chemical properties because they have the same number of {{c1::electrons}}.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Electrons determine chemical behaviour. Since isotopes have the same proton count, they have the same electron count and chemical properties.

toLevel3.question: Whether an isotope is stable or radioactive depends on the {{c1::proton-to-neutron ratio}} in its nucleus.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Nuclear forces depend on the balance between protons and neutrons. An unfavourable ratio leads to instability and radioactive decay.

toLevel3.question: Isotopes differ in their {{c1::physical}} properties, such as mass and density.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Different neutron numbers give isotopes different masses, affecting physical properties while chemical properties remain the same.

toLevel3.question: The radioactivity of an isotope is determined by its electron configuration.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Radioactivity is a nuclear property determined by the proton-to-neutron ratio in the nucleus, not by electrons.

toLevel3.question: Carbon-12 and Carbon-14 will react identically in chemical reactions.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Both have 6 protons and 6 electrons, giving identical chemical properties despite their different masses.

toLevel4.question: Chlorine has two stable isotopes: Cl-35 (75.77%) and Cl-37 (24.23%). Calculate the approximate average atomic mass of chlorine.

distractorExplanations.36.0 u: This doesn't account for the higher abundance of the lighter isotope.
distractorExplanations.35.0 u: This ignores the contribution of Cl-37 to the average mass.
distractorExplanations.37.0 u: This would require Cl-37 to be dominant, but Cl-35 is more abundant.

toLevel4.question: Uranium-235 and Uranium-238 are both used in nuclear applications. How many more neutrons does U-238 have than U-235?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: U-235: 235 - 92 = 143 neutrons. U-238: 238 - 92 = 146 neutrons. Difference: 146 - 143 = 3 neutrons.

distractorExplanations.92: This is the number of protons in both isotopes.
distractorExplanations.143: This is the number of neutrons in U-235, not the difference.
distractorExplanations.146: This is the number of neutrons in U-238, not the difference.

toLevel4.question: A sample contains Carbon-12 and Carbon-14 in equal amounts. If only Carbon-14 is radioactive, what percentage of the sample will decay over time?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Only Carbon-14 (half the sample) is radioactive and will decay. Carbon-12 (the other half) is stable.

distractorExplanations.100%: Carbon-12 is stable and will not decay.
distractorExplanations.0%: Carbon-14 is radioactive and will decay.
distractorExplanations.14%: 14 is the mass number of C-14, not the percentage that decays.

toLevel4.question: Heavy water (D₂O) is used in some nuclear reactors. How does the mass of a heavy water molecule compare to regular water (H₂O)?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Each deuterium (mass 2) replaces hydrogen (mass 1), adding 1 u per atom. With 2 hydrogen atoms, the total difference is 2 u.

distractorExplanations.About 2 u lighter: Deuterium is heavier than hydrogen, not lighter.
distractorExplanations.Identical mass: Deuterium has one more neutron than hydrogen, making D₂O heavier.
distractorExplanations.About 4 u heavier: Each D is only 1 u heavier than H, so 2 D atoms add only 2 u.

toLevel4.question: Potassium-40 (K-40) is a naturally occurring radioactive isotope. If stable K-39 has 20 neutrons, how many neutrons does K-40 have?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: K-40 has mass number 40 with 19 protons, so it has 40 - 19 = 21 neutrons, one more than K-39.

distractorExplanations.20: This is the neutron count for K-39, not K-40.
distractorExplanations.19: This is the number of protons in both isotopes.
distractorExplanations.40: This is the mass number of K-40, not the neutron count.

toLevel4.question: Oxygen-16 has 8 neutrons, so Oxygen-18 has {{c1::10}} neutrons.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Oxygen has 8 protons. O-16: 16 - 8 = 8 neutrons. O-18: 18 - 8 = 10 neutrons (2 more than O-16).

toLevel4.question: The average atomic mass of an element depends on the {{c1::relative abundance}} of its isotopes.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: The weighted average of isotope masses, based on their natural abundances, gives the element's atomic mass.

toLevel4.question: Tritium (³₁H) has {{c1::2}} more neutrons than protium (¹₁H).
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Protium: 1 - 1 = 0 neutrons. Tritium: 3 - 1 = 2 neutrons. Difference: 2 - 0 = 2 neutrons.

toLevel4.question: If an element has only one naturally occurring stable isotope, its atomic mass will be a whole number.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: With only one stable isotope, the atomic mass equals that isotope's mass number (a whole number), with no weighted averaging needed.

toLevel4.question: Neon-20 and Argon-20 are isotopes of the same element because they have the same mass number.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Same mass number means they are isobars, not isotopes. Neon has 10 protons; Argon has 18. They are different elements.

toLevel5.question: A scientist needs to track carbon in a biological system over several years. Why would Carbon-14 be preferred over a hypothetical Carbon-15 (if it existed with a half-life of seconds)?
options: C-14's long half-life allows detection over years, while C-15 would decay immediately
C-15 would have identical chemical properties to C-12
toLevel5.correct: C-14's long half-life allows detection over years, while C-15 would decay immediately
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Carbon-14's half-life of 5730 years allows it to remain detectable over the study period. A seconds-long half-life would make tracking impossible.

distractorExplanations.C-15 would have identical chemical prope: Both C-14 and C-15 would have identical chemistry to C-12; this doesn't explain the preference.
distractorExplanations.C-14 is cheaper to produce: Cost is not the primary consideration; detection capability is.
distractorExplanations.C-15 would be more radioactive: Higher activity would actually be detectable, but instant decay would prevent tracking.

toLevel5.question: In uranium enrichment for nuclear fuel, U-235 is separated from U-238. Why is this separation difficult despite them being isotopes?
options: They have nearly identical chemical properties and only slightly different masses
They have completely different chemical properties
U-235 is much heavier than U-238
toLevel5.correct: They have nearly identical chemical properties and only slightly different masses
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Isotopes have identical chemistry, so chemical separation is impossible. The 1.3% mass difference (235 vs 238) makes physical separation challenging.

distractorExplanations.They have completely different chemical: Isotopes have identical chemical properties, making chemical separation impossible.
distractorExplanations.U-235 is much heavier than U-238: U-235 is actually lighter (by 3 mass units) than U-238.
distractorExplanations.They cannot exist together: Natural uranium contains both isotopes mixed together.

toLevel5.question: Archaeologists use the ratio of C-14 to C-12 in organic remains for dating. Why does this ratio change after an organism dies?
options: C-14 decays radioactively while C-12 remains constant
Both isotopes decay at the same rate
The ratio never changes after death
toLevel5.correct: C-14 decays radioactively while C-12 remains constant
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Living organisms maintain a constant C-14/C-12 ratio by exchanging carbon with the environment. After death, C-14 decays while stable C-12 does not, changing the ratio.

distractorExplanations.C-12 decays faster than C-14: C-12 is stable and does not decay at all.
distractorExplanations.Both isotopes decay at the same rate: Only C-14 is radioactive; C-12 is stable.
distractorExplanations.The ratio never changes after death: The ratio decreases as C-14 decays, which is the basis for radiocarbon dating.

toLevel5.question: Heavy water (D₂O) slows neutrons more effectively than regular water in nuclear reactors. This is due to differences in which property between isotopes?
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Deuterium's higher mass changes how energy is transferred in neutron collisions. This is a physical property difference between isotopes.

distractorExplanations.Chemical reactivity with neutrons: Neutron moderation is a nuclear/physical process, not a chemical one.
distractorExplanations.Electron configuration: Isotopes have identical electron configurations; this doesn't explain the difference.

toLevel5.question: A mass spectrometer separates ions by mass-to-charge ratio. When analysing a sample of neon, three peaks appear at masses 20, 21, and 22. What does this indicate?
options: Neon has three naturally occurring isotopes
The sample is contaminated with other elements
Neon atoms have lost different numbers of electrons
toLevel5.correct: Neon has three naturally occurring isotopes
toLevel5.correctExplanation: The three peaks at consecutive mass numbers indicate Ne-20, Ne-21, and Ne-22, which are the three stable isotopes of neon.

distractorExplanations.The sample is contaminated with other el: Consecutive mass numbers near neon's atomic mass strongly suggest isotopes, not contaminants.
distractorExplanations.The spectrometer is malfunctioning: Multiple distinct peaks indicate successful separation of isotopes.
distractorExplanations.Neon atoms have lost different numbers o: Different charge states would show in the mass-to-charge ratio calculation, not as separate mass peaks.

toLevel5.question: Isotope separation is difficult because isotopes have identical {{c1::chemical properties}} and only small mass differences.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Chemical methods cannot separate isotopes since they behave identically in reactions. Only physical methods exploiting mass differences work.

toLevel5.question: Radiocarbon dating works because the ratio of C-14 to C-12 decreases predictably after an organism {{c1::dies}}.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Death stops carbon exchange with the environment, allowing the C-14/C-12 ratio to decrease as C-14 decays.

toLevel5.question: The relative peak heights in a mass spectrum of an element indicate the {{c1::natural abundance}} of its isotopes.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Higher peaks correspond to more abundant isotopes, allowing determination of isotopic composition.

toLevel5.question: Isotopes can be separated using standard chemical filtration techniques.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Isotopes have identical chemical properties, so chemical methods cannot separate them. Physical methods exploiting mass differences (centrifugation, diffusion) are required.

toLevel5.question: The discovery of isotopes explained why some elements have non-integer atomic masses on the periodic table.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Atomic masses are weighted averages of naturally occurring isotope masses. Multiple isotopes with different abundances produce non-integer averages.
